job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist (CST) in Cleveland, OH
pros: Metro is a very good place to work, I loved what they stand for and the patients they treat everyone was always so so grateful. Felt respected here, overall great experience
cons: Level 1 trauma hospital can be mentally and physically demanding

pros: The Healthcare Benefits and Retirement Plans are two things that are very hard to compete with anywhere else.
cons: You will not get an annual raise, you will have to fight for any income change justification, you will be overworked, underplayed, and undervalued. You will see significant favoritism and less than ethical practices. Middle management sometimes listens, but unfortunately Executive level management doesn’t. The atmosphere was mostly about money and profit, not providing the best level of care for our clients. For being THE county hospital and also a non-profit organization, that didn’t ever sit well with me. You will find Physicians, Nurses, Clinicians, and other professionals who have such recognizable burnout that they should not be treating patients, and yet no corrective action is ever taken. Bullying in the workplace is real and incredibly prevalent in several departmental areas throughout the MHS. It wasn’t always like this, It started out as my dream job, and place to work, I thought I would retire here. After 2 years, that quickly declined due to poor Executive management that trickled down through the system.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician in Cleveland, OH
pros: The money for an MLT is amazing. No other hospital pays the amount you’ll get at MetroHealth. There is overtime available in excess. The people you would work with in the lab are amazing. You are a part of OPERS and a union.
cons: The management in the lab is lacking. They don’t seem to realize we are people. The forced mandation. If someone calls off and the next shift is short, you can be mandated to stay, sometimes the whole shift. You get paid overtime but it really can be awful if you have to stay overnight. Everything is done by seniority. Getting jobs, vacation etc. If you are newly hired, you don’t really get anything good. There is really no room for growth.

job_title: Inpatient Pharmacy Technician in Cleveland, OH
pros: Pay, benefits, hours, and retirement are all top notch. For the most part the people you are working with are good to work with as well. They provide an indepth training program for all jobs on all shifts so prior experience isn't a major concern.
cons: Work is dependent on the number of patients so how hard you work will be inconsistent in many cases. Management has a tendency to give you something to do if they find you being unproductive. The only real crappy thing is the mandation system. If there is a call off for the next shift someone from the current shift will be required to stay until the required tasks are done. This usually means the whole shift if evening shift calls off, 3-4 hours if night shift calls off, and 1-3 hours if day shifts calls off. The silver lining is you earn time and 1 half for this assuming you are full time.

pros: I have worked for MetroHeath in different capacities as a physician for over 10 years. I have held various leadership roles within the organization. Staff are generally friendly and committed to the mission of the organization to care for the underserved. Healthcare benefits and retirement are good, though the governmental pension benefit is not nearly as good as in the past, with reductions for new hires compared with older pension groups receiving a grandfathered higher pension benefit not available to new workers.
cons:
Organization is extremely top-down. Most providers feel like a commodity, with little institutional support for providers in the form of resources, staff, and equipment. The incentive compensation plan only rewards clinical productivity and punishes academic work and non-clinical leadership work. Your departmental Chairperson is tasked with meeting the requests of the CEO/CMO, not responding to the needs of individual providers.

In the decade I have been with the organization, I have never heard from nor seen hospital leadership (outside of highly produced videos from the CEO). There is no pathway or channel to escalate personal or departmental concerns above your Chair.

MetroHealth seems to be desperately struggling to be known for something, anything, but they aren’t sure what yet, so they are throwing everything at the wall hoping something sticks. Concierge medicine, teleheath, imaging centers, diversity initiatives, community medicine centers, dentistry. You name it, they are throwing dollars at it, hoping at least one thing will work so they can escape the long shadows of the Cleveland Clinic and UH. Unfortunate, they are hemorrhaging money in the process, so actual good patient care and working for the underserved gets lost in the shuffle. You could certainly choose to work here, just be prepared that as a provider, no one will care about you or your problems after day 1. 

Oh, and they are building a beautiful new hospital but conveniently forgot to include space for faculty offices, meeting room, teaching spaces, etc. Just more evidence that providers and staff are secondary to the vision and aspirations of the CEO.

pros: Benefits and coworkers are great

review_title: Great efforts to combat COVID and Physician Burn out
pros:
-Opportunities to develop a niche
-A big enough practice that there is always someone to cover in the event of illness/vacation
-robust efforts to combat physician burn out
- MetroHealth has really taken care of its staff and the Cleveland community during COVID by having great testing, immunizing us early, and pivoting to telemedicine
cons:
- deteriorating physical plant (and I am not sure the transformation is addressing our outpatient building)
- Inadequate reimbursement for continuing medical education (CME) expenses and no reimbursement for Ohio medical license expenses

review_title: The MetroHealth System is a great place to work...Focused on providing Hope!
job_title: Manager in Brooklyn Heights, Cuyahoga, OH
pros: My coworkers at all levels are engaging and extremely helpful in assisting me adjust to the new surroundings, organization policies and processes. The leadership of the organization is employee focused, and committed to creating a team of dedicated employees, representing all levels, all races, and genders. The organization is focused on employees understanding a implementing the "social determinates of health". It has been a challenge joining the team during the COVID 19 pandemic. But it gave me a real opportunity observe the organization at all levels, and all departments, pivot and continue to provide high level service during an extremely difficult time. They are creating a organization-wide attitude of "Hope" in the employees, the community, and the people we serve.
cons: Need to assure we have the infrastructure to continue the work, and meet the goals.

review_title: Meaningful employment making a difference in Cleveland
job_title: Bariatric Surgery Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: As the bariatric coordinator I can attest that MetroHealth is constantly trying to improve employee benefits. We have excellent healthcare plans, access to employee only dental clinics, employee discounts on specific services, and we were among the first in Ohio to receive the COVID-19 vaccines. More importantly to me, though, is that MetroHealth is constantly working to improve the city of Cleveland and surrounding areas. Being a part of the MetroHealth family means being a part of something bigger than yourself and putting good out in the world. Even as the bariatric program coordinator, I have opportunities to join different professional groups that work on providing leadership training, increasing participation in Green initiatives, and even making a commitment to increase inclusion and diversity throughout the system. The team here is like family and I am excited to see where my career at MH takes me.
cons: Right now the biggest inconveniences are related to COVID, such as the pedestrian bridge and employee gym being closed.

cons: The politics at times can feel overwhelming but you get this at any organization and Metro has been good to me professionally and personally. I love this organization and plan to remain for another 15 years. I have a daughter working in the organization and she planning to be a nurse here when she completes her schooling. There is no other place she wants to work (must have been all those stories I shared) as she grew up at MetroHealth.

pros: I have worked at The MetroHealth System for 12 years and I cannot have ever imagined working for such an amazing organization. From the first day I began working and to this day, I can easily say the is the BEST! Since we have had a national emergency with COVID19, The MetroHealth System has stepped up in every way possible to make sure that the workers and backbone of the organization is protected. We have had, and still have, the proper COVID19 precautions; PPE, organization support, training and daily updates from the organization. Our leader, Dr. Boutros, has been amazing and supportive, proactive and has transformed our mission and our community. I believe that there is no other organization that could stand up next to The MetroHealth System. Our organization has responded to the COVID19 pandemic exceptionally and has allocated proper PPE to every single employee and has dedicated COVID units so that our community doesn't suffer and neither will the employees. The MetroHealth System is simply the best!!
cons: I do not see there being any cons to working for The MetroHealth System.

job_title: Information Services Employee in Cleveland, OH
pros:
I've been working at Metrohealth for over 4 years, which is a relatively short period of time compared to many of the other employees here, and there is a reason for that kind of retention - the culture here is rare to find, it's people-centered. It's not just about the caring for patients, which is of course the highest priority, but it's about promoting a supportive, caring mind-set through the organization. A lot of organizations have mission statements and values but my experience with Metrohealth is that those things are practiced every day by staff and it shows. Being in Information Services (our IT department) I get to work directly with all departments, from EVS, Public Safety, Human Resources and Clinical staff, and throughout, everyone holds the concepts of 'Service to others' and 'Teamwork' to the highest regards.

What brought me here to do this review was my experiences over the past few months; I wanted to emphasize how this culture has helped us during the COVID-19 pandemic; very early on it was clear that changes were necessary to prepare ourselves for what was coming and steps were taken quickly by various departments. While the pandemic is nowhere near over, our ability to adapt quickly makes me very confident and happy to be working here! I would absolutely recommend applying to anyone who is looking to join an organization where people come first.
cons: None that I can think of.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Cleveland, OH
pros: Good pay, great teamwork involved
cons: None that I can think of

pros: Great teaching hospital! Depending on your craft, this is a fantastic place to perfect it. At the end of the day the repitition and experience gained is unparalleled.
cons: Scheduling is based on seniority and many floors operate on a two week day/night rotation. Sometimes the turnaround is less than 24 hrs which can be brutal. We don't use PTO instead it's separated into vacation and sick time. Starting in 2016, we can only accumulate 1.5 times your vacation. The problem is if you are low on seniority you'll never get to use the vacation when it is ideal. But if you don't use it you'll no longer acrue additional vacation. So you can take a day a week or a full week in September after the kids are back in school. Sick time is a joke only because we operate on a points system therefore if you use it for any thing other than FMLA you risk your job.

review_title: Great company to begin and continue your career!
pros: I stared with this company 13 years ago. Back then, larger hospital systems in the area were offering sign on bonuses and gifts to come work in their organizations. A wise nursing instructor advised I not overlook what Metrohealth has to offer. OPERS, Affordable benefits, growth opportunities. I can honestly say, I plan to retire from this organization. This hospital also invests in staff. Education reimbursement  and scholarships are frequently offered. Pay is comparable, if not higher than other area hospitals.
cons: Like with any organization - there is always room for improvement. I would like to see greater investment in facilities - especially at main campus. Not just building new buildings but maybe increasing house keeping staff visibility. Clean the carpets frequently, etc.

pros: Having a job and close to home
cons: Terrible pay and toxic work environment

review_title: Not as good as it was
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Parma, OH
pros: Benefits and pay rate are very good.
cons: Staffing ratios are not appropriate.

review_title: Not thrilled, but not terrible either
pros:
County hospital so you get holidays that other companies don't get like MLK, Veteran's day if you choose to take it. 

Good benefits plan- medical, dental, vision. 

They give you a chance and you are expected to learn, grow.
cons:
You are expected to see X number of patients daily. This is emphasized quite a bit. Revenue is very important to them rather than quality of care many times. 

Not really loving the work environment. You can feel the stress. And some are just not great to work with, especially the providers at a particular satellite. 

the patient population is difficult to work with. Many times they dont' show and it's hard to help those who don't want it. 

Too many people doing the same job in administration. What used to be 1 position, is now split up into 3. Who do we go to for xyz problem? It's a matter of going from one person to another until you're told it will be handled. 

Sometimes they hire incompetent, unprofessional people into management roles. And you just have to work with them even if they aren't your supervisor.

review_title: Great for experience but will make you dislike nursing
job_title: Registered Nurse in Cleveland Heights, Cuyahoga, OH
pros: You will often get a 45 min lunch. It is hard to find a nursing career where taking lunch is in the culture.
cons: You have to watch 10 patients while your assigned nurse partner takes lunch.

review_title: An Amazing Blend of Love, Compassion and Community
job_title: Senior Vice President, Chief Diversity and Human Resources Officer in Cleveland, OH
pros: At MetroHealth, one of the first things that people notice upon entering a facility is that employees (regardless of position, department or title) genuinely care about making a difference in the lives of their patients and the community at large. I’ve had countless visitors say to me that they “feel something different” when they arrive and “this place is special” when they exit.  While it is a dynamic, fast paced environment, there is a laser-like focus on adhering to the mission, vision and values of the organization. The commitment to building a healthier community is evident by the organization’s willingness to “get it’s hands dirty” and be on the front lines in terms of health equity, advocacy and accessibility. It is feel honored and blessed to wake up each morning knowing that the work that I do matters and the organization that I work for is passionate and “all in” with making Greater Cleveland, Cuyahoga County and the entire Northeast Ohio region a healthier, and safer place for EVERYONE!
cons: While no organization is perfect and no organization ever will be, it is very apparent that the senior leadership team is committed to not settling for mediocrity.

review_title: The Great and Not So Great
pros: The CEO that came on a few years back, Dr. Butros, is absolutely fantastic. Visits the floors, very personable with staff, patients and visitors. When he first started here he greeted people in front lobby, brought coffee and papers to the patients. His staff comes and checks on patients. He also thanks the staff.  New garage helps with parking.
cons: Even though Metro is trying to help employees who are being harassed, bullied and dealing with a hostile working environment, the fact that those doing the harassment have friends and coworkers who will also back their dishonest behavior. This doesn't allow the policy meant to help employees, actually get put to work . We are afraid of losing our job if we speak up. No one will believe us. We go back to the same environment or management tries to smear you if you try and leave.

pros: My journey with MetroHealth has spanned two separate decades (1981-1993) and (2012 to the present) a total of 19 years.  The joy of returning to MetroHealth has included the rekindling of old relationships, developing new ones, and returning to an organization that makes a difference. MetroHealth stands for quality care to everyone. It is about inclusion, diversity, family, caring, compassion and supporting our community.  It is not simply a job. It is a way of sharing our talents and giving to others that is both meaningful and fulfilling.
cons: MetroHealth does not have an up to date main campus (yet!)  We recognize our need to improve and adapt. We are embracing transformation and positive change as we expand our ambulatory network, construct a new main campus, revitalize the 25th Street Corridor, and the implement the latest of healthcare technologies.

pros: Metro is not a great place to wok
cons: Do not work here if you can avoid it

review_title: Current employee considering a move due to poor supervision and management.
pros: Hospital mission; those that stay do so because they believe in the mission of helping the less fortunate; Benefits
cons: Top heavy administration with little oversight on individual departments who supervise and manage with punitiveness. When one attempts to make a lateral move they are stonewalled by immediate supervisors. Human Resources tend to label and refuse to consider one for other types of jobs if it doesn't fit with one degree, therefore there is no room for ad an enemy. My department has lost many excellent professionals in the last several years due to the culture of the department and management style. Yet, middle and upper management continue to bury their heads and keep the department beads, who are responsible for so many employees departing, intact. Since the new CEO has taken over morale is even lower.

pros: MetroHealth has been a place where I have been able to grow both personally and professionally. I feel that I have a great sense of autonomy in the work that I do and am supported by leadership. During the COVID-19 pandemic MetroHealth we had to make changes very quickly to prepare for the worst, we quickly adapted to remote work and new technologies, and even became stronger and more connected in our teams. On site, safety was the primary concern and MetroHealth did an amazing job at ensuring all our of staff and patients were safe by ensuring everyone had access to masks and proper PPE; we conduct temperature checks of employees and patients entering our sites and have increased cleaning measures. We've continued to Additionally, MetroHealth was one of the few healthcare systems in the nation to not lay off or furlough employees during the crisis, and were even able to give a general increase raise to all of their non union employees. MetroHealth also has great benefits including amazing health insurance, investment options, and great vacation and sick time policies.
cons: N/A - I love being part of the MHS team!

job_title: Director, Individual Giving in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: MetroHealth staff reflects the people we serve - a diverse group of committed individuals who care about those who need health services.  Hiring, training, recruitment, disciplinary actions are all handled at a very professional level.  You have to care about the mission to work here but if you do, you will see that you are doing meaningful work to improve the lives of those who live in Greater Cleveland.
cons: Change takes time - facilities are not in great shape but to repair things might take a bit.  things 'move up and down' the food chain slowly.  With some folks off campus now, they are not able to access all the benefits of main campus.  Very few federal days off - but we are a hospital, after all.

pros: Decent healthcare benefits and some very dedicated staff.
cons: Management shows favoritism for the employees they hired and punitiveness to those they did not. Despite informing HR and the Union about management's unethical and retaliatory behavior and having tangible evidence to support the claim, HR nor the Union acted and did nothing to assist. The message received was that unfortunately there is no process for review of supervisors and or management by employees and once targeted the employee better have an exit strategy. Additionally, vacation and sick time are separate. Sick time is based on a point system, 8 points per day. If one acquires 24 points a written warning is given with a warning about termination. Thus, if one is unfortunate to get sick one risks employment status unless FMLA is applied for and approved. So every employee with any type of healthcare issue has FMLA papers on file...a complete misuse of the FMLA law.

review_title: The worst employment experience I have ever had
job_title: Research in Brooklyn Heights, Cuyahoga, OH
pros:
1. Health care insurance benefits are exceptional in terms of cost.
2. The hospital's main campus is fairly accessible off a major highway.
cons:
1. The Department of Human Resources at MetroHealth is a perfect example of why employees complain about HR. After informing HR of ongoing and unresolved issues involving verbally combative employees and illegal/unethical practices occurring within the department I worked in, HR did absolutely nothing to assist, even after I received retaliatory treatment. 

2. The hospital speaks of larger plans of grandeur and making a world-class facility for patients, but completely disregards management of employees within the hospital system. There is no process for review of supervisors/management by employees and there is a complete lack of communication. 

3. Fees for employee parking at the main hospital campus is automatically taken out of paychecks, but there is NO guarantee that employees will actually have parking on campus.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician in Cleveland, OH
pros:
The hospital mission is great and precisely the kind of place I want to spend my career.
Pay is great for MLT, okay for MLS
Sick time rolls over and never expires
Pension, retirement options, and health coverage is very competitive. 
Union!!!!
cons:
Vacation time is fairly weak.  24 years needed to get to 5 weeks paid vacation which is way more than it should be.  Start off with 2 weeks your first 5 years which is pretty standard, but it takes a lot of years of service to go above 3 weeks(18 for 4 weeks I believe).  Healthcare is demanding, we should have more time off.  

The lab is very old, and equipment needs to be updated.  Hopefully with the new hospital this changes.

review_title: MetroHealth is the place for you!
job_title: RN BSN Childbirth Education Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: I believe today's experiences of our babies and families influence their health down the road.   I work at  MetroHealth as a nurse because the leadership here strongly believes that, too. The collective mission is to lift all members of the community up and provide care to all.  People here believe in that mission.  I love the fact that this hospital and its leadership truly gets that it is housing, jobs, food access, schools, and where you live that really impacts your health.  I have worked at other hospitals and Metro simply does the best job of this.   If you are looking for a place to work that allows you to influence and create change in a person's life by impacting the community they live in, not just at their appointments or during hospital stays, then this is the place for you.  I am proud to be a part of the MetroHealth community.
cons: I can't really think of any.

pros: There’s no question that all hospitals were challenged by the arrival of COVID19. I was so glad we had Dr. Boutros as our leader when the virus slapped us in the face. Of utmost importance to Dr. Boutros is the safety and well-being of everyone in the MetroHealth family and he remains committed to keeping our patients, staff, and visitors safe throughout this entire ordeal. Under his leadership, ALL employees (not just those in direct patient care areas) were provided with masks; all employees were kept abreast of the impact the virus had on our operations; all employees were able to keep their jobs with some being reassigned to different areas so they weren’t laid off or furloughed. And while other hospitals were rescinding wage increases, Dr. Boutros made sure employees received theirs in recognition of their hard work, loyalty, and dedication. During this very challenging time, it feels good to know that Dr. Boutros has our backs!
cons: There are no downsides to being part of the MetroHealth family!

review_title: Proud to work within the MetroHealth System for 18+ years
pros: MetroHealth is guided by a mission that puts care of patients and community above all else. The culture is to put patients first and there is a new thrust to address social determinants of health and improving the community surrounding the MetroHealth Medical Center. There is gratitude and respect for employees- particularly notable in the COVID19 pandemic- in which a pay raise was given when other systems were laying off employees. As an employee within the system, I've felt that my safety in regards to COVID19 was of utmost importance. I'm grateful to work at MHS.
cons: Some of the facilities are dated and show their age, though a new hospital is being constructed. The MetroHealth System is underrated due to smaller marketing budget compared to other Cleveland healthcare systems.

pros: MetroHealth is the kind of place that those who went into healthcare because they really wanted to help others and make a positive difference in the world will be at home. Its charitable mission stretching all the way back to its founding as City Hospital in 1836 with its academic and research mission reaching at least back to 1914 when it became an affiliate of what is now Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, it is a truly remarkable academic teaching hospital and one of Northeast Ohio's relatively unheralded jewels.
cons: All institutions face challenges, especially those like MetroHealth that aim to deliver the highest quality health care to largely underserved, underinsured, and indigent populations. You have to be willing to try to rise to meet these challenges every day.

review_title: "I've never been prouder to work for MetroHealth"
pros: Since March 9th, with the first cases of COVID-19 in our county, MetroHealth has acted fast and with purpose to support our community, especially the underserved. We established a 24/7 physician-staffed hotline, a mobile testing unit, and wrap-around services to ensure that our patients needing to quarantine have the resources they need. In primary care, we reached out to all of our patients with chronic conditions, to connect them to their medical team and make sure that during the early stages of the pandemic, they still have help maintaining their health. I've heard from colleagues all over the system that in all their years here, they've never been prouder to work for MetroHealth than right now.
cons: Looking forward to moving out of our old hospital and into the new one. Our patients and employees deserve it.

review_title: It's all about our patients and our community!
job_title: Director of Advanced Practice Registered Nursing in Cleveland, OH
pros: I have worked at MetroHealth for over 30 years and it is all about our patients. We are here to give world-class care to everyone, regardless of ability to pay. It is an excellent place to work for Advanced Practice Providers . We have had nurse practitioners at Metro for more than 40 years and encourage the highest level of scope and practice. Our CEO is passionate about our community and giving more than just health care to all. He is an innovator with a vision and heart for people.
cons: I have seen no organization that is perfect but we keep trying to be the best for everyone, patients and staff alike.

review_title: Timelines and numbers force narrow thinking
pros: Great benefits and opportunity for growth. Most employees treat you as part of the family. Vision and Mission had a positive makeover. Community impact is wonderful to see. Transformation looks promising. ThinkTank and other company events are a positive change.
cons: Hard to teach an old dog new tricks. Organization suffers from groupthink at most levels of leadership. No incentives to work hard or rewards for those who do. Inconsistent communication, terrible recruiting with outdated roles and descriptions. Organization does not hold people accountable and let's them "ride the pine" to avoid conflict. Beginning to cut quality for quantity.

pros: From the moment you start your career at MetroHealth you feel part of something life changing.  You quickly learn about the heroes that you work with,  the life changing moments, the passion and compassion, the care and soul of the organization. This isn't just a job.   You have become a part of a community of educators, caregivers, lifesavers, community advocates, counselors, coaches, mentors ....people that make an impact every day.
cons: We need to be innovative in attracting the millenial workforce.

job_title: Senior Executive Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros: During Dr. Boutros’ opening remarks at orientation, he told us that at MetroHealth, there are caregivers and individuals who “care for the Caregivers”.  I happen to fall in the latter of the two and come to work each day knowing that I help make a difference in people’s lives.  From day one, the MetroHealth community embraced me and made me feel welcomed.    I am fortunate to be able to work with kind, intelligent and talented individuals every day.   MetroHealth’s teamwork is remarkable, I have witnessed this daily assisting with COVID-19.   There isn’t anywhere else I would rather be.
cons: I am unable to think of any.

review_title: They don't just have a mission, they live it out
job_title: Media Relations Specialist in Brooklyn Heights, Cuyahoga, OH
pros: I love the team work here! Every employee in my department works to help someone else, whether it's internal or external. There's no shortage of help, either. I started one month ago and everyone makes you feel like you've been there for years. Supportive, not awkward to the "new girl" and very helpful. Plus, the community outreach is great! During the COVID-19 pandemic, it's been amazing to see how everyone has pulled together to take care of people in need. New programs are being created and old programs are being revamped t to serve the community. I'm happy to be part of this team.
cons: I haven't been there long enough to find the downsides yet!

review_title: Good place to work with great down to earth knowledgeable people.
pros: Hardworking patient centered people. Many check their egos at the door to work in a collaborative effort. The leaders that are non-contract help and are real advocates for their employees with no hidden agendas.
cons: The contract people, yes we do need change workflow and process control but dont bring in 50 million consultants to do it. Do the leg work and assessments yourself to meet the workers and get their spin on things. It is our jobs and customers you are affecting.

pros:
There are many options for healthcare leaders in Cleveland. I chose MetroHealth for the people, the  caring heart and the trajectory.  MetroHealth is blazing the trails that other public hospitals work to emulate.
 The Nurses are Magnet accredited placing them in the top 6% of nurses nationally. The nurse and physician collaboration and respect are unparalleled. 
 Our senior leadership has taken us from surviving to thriving and the next five years of transformation will bring even more opportunity. We are tenacious. We are resilient and we are committed to one another and our city. We do not stand in the shadow of giants. We are giants!
cons: There are no cons to working here.

pros: Excellent place to work. Feel respected as a leader, autonomy to protect and serve MH employees and the community, flexible hours, great benefits, and multiple educational resources for staff. During Covid-19 pandemic, the Executive team has taken quick and decisive measures to protect patients and staff. Excellent communication and daily updates for all employees, state of the art technology for testing capabilities and in house mask sterilization. Modification of human resources attendance policies to provide realistic expectations for staff and their families.
cons: A lot of construction going on at this time around the Campus.

pros: Pay is higher than any health system I have worked for. Vacation and pto (sick time) is seperate allowing you to take a vacation and not worry about using your hours if you need them. Benefits are MUCH less expensive than other health systems I have worked for. Even being less expensive, incentives are offered for being proactive in your health (going to a primary care doctor, getting your teeth cleaned, etc) will get you a discount. You do not lose the discount if you don't lose weight! Retirement benefits are great.
cons: At this time I have not run into any cons. Maybe paying for parking but even that is less expensive than other big health systems in the are.

review_title: A Great Community Based Hospital with a Vision for the Future
pros: MetroHealth is improving and on the rise. The vision for the future is aggressive and not what you'd expect from a county hospital. There's a lot of great people here with a lot of great ideas. From an employee standpoint, they offer good wages, plenty of opportunity, and great benefits.
cons: The only con I see, as with any public held entity, is how things get done. There's often a lot of procedural activities which add a lot of cost to operations and projects. Not that this is wrong, but there's always room to improve.

review_title: Great mission but challenging economic system means underpaid staff
pros: The mission of Metrohealth is to provide care to all without regard for ability to pay; this leads to some great and dedicated staff who want to work urban poor populations. Great teaching hospital, with opportunities for clinicians to become heavily involved in resident education. Good benefits for medical staff, including sick time separate from vacation time. Good retirement benefits.
cons: Lots of cuts due to tightening finances; not much news from higher management. There was a notable gap in clinicians with a lot of newer folks (under 7 years at the hospital) leaving for other jobs. Low salaries relative to other hospitals.

pros: I was looking for something more than a job. I found that at MetroHealth. Every single individual I’ve interacted with since coming to this institution is here for the right reason: the desire to improve the health and well-being of our community. It might not have the panache of the other health systems in town, but the heart of this institution is unrivaled. Also, the benefits are strong and the compensation is competitive.
cons: Some of the facilities and technology are dated, but MetroHealth is building a brand-new hospital that will rival any health care facility. It's an exciting time to work at MetroHealth because of the potential that's being unlocked.

review_title: Amazing and wonderful place to work
pros: MetroHealth has recruited top doctors, nurses, and professionals who work together as a team for the patients. We work hard but everyone helps everyone else.  Great salary, thanksgiving food cards ($25) for EVERY employee. Looking forward to a new hospital in 2021.
cons: Expansion to Parma, Cleveland Heights, Bedford, and Brecksville strained staff for the first few months.  Now things are much better with almost 500 new employees recruited last year.

pros: At MetroHealth  everyone is part of the team ~ we are all needed to be successful! Whether we are a starter or the reliever without everyone's contribution we would not be successful!There's always a backup willing and able to help assist us. Anyone looking to get a job in the Healthcare community in Cleveland should realize MetroHealth is the best system to work for~ unanimously the best career choice for healthcare workers! Everyone wants to be drafted to MetroHealth and be part of the line up.
cons: Our growth ahead leaves some unknowns~ until the expansion project is complete there are challenges of relocation and what lies ahead.

job_title: Vice President Ambulatory Operations & Integration in Cleveland, OH
pros: Providing care to all individuals in  all communities with or without the ability to pay.  Doing this with passion and always putting the patients first. The clinical and non clinical staff are excellent and will go the extra mile for their patients and family members.
cons: As with any health system  that experiences exponential growth,  the  ability to provide  access to specialists as quick as patients request can be challenging.

review_title: The health system provides an amazing service for the community, but executive management is truly uninspiring.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Cleveland, OH
pros: Metro employs some of the best and most dedicated medical and professional staff I have seen. The community it supports would be terribly impacted if services were ever reduced.
cons: During my short tenure (less than one year), both the CFO and COO postions were changed twice.  Each time there was a radically different vision for how the financial and operations should be handled.

job_title: Medical Receptionist / Practice Support in Cleveland, OH
pros: It's a nice community based hospital and the staff is pleasant.
cons: Don't consider working here unless you are a floor sweeper or cafeteria aide.  The pay is very poor.  Management offers no  performance pay increases.  You could bend over backwards year after year and they don't consider raises. In fact, when one department exceeded goals year after year, an employee asked for a raise and was told 'No, we don't give raises. This isn't Cleveland Clinic '.  When the department does well financially, the only people rewarded are upper management.

review_title: Initially positive but has now become rather dismal and punishing.
pros:
Retirement package among the best in the city. This is what retains most members of the staff 
Good staff to work with.
cons:
Poor communication from leadership. 
Excessive levels of leadership without any impact on patient care. 
We do not follow our values
Increased emphasis on revenue generation without adequate resources to provide effective patient care. Malignant towards many of their best resources.

pros: I wanted to work at a place that makes a positive difference in people's lives, and that's what I found at MetroHealth. This health system not only heals seriously ill and injured patients, it also contributes to the community around it, taking steps to improve lives and the health of the people it serves.
cons: Working in health care is a 24/7 business, so there's not a lot of "disconnected" time, but that would be the case working at any hospital system.

review_title: MetroHealth is a great place to go to work every day!
pros: The mission of MetroHealth System is the heart and soul of this organization. We are a safety net for all of Cuyahoga County. Employees works together to fulfill the mission and serve our patients.  This is a time of growth and transformation at MetroHealth which is exciting to be a part of as an employee. MetroHealth is a great place to work with a common desire among the workforce to take care of our community. Visionary management taking the hospital and services to a new level.
cons: No complaints. Love my time as an employee at MetroHealth.

pros: The inter-professional collaboration and teamwork is phenomenal! Nurses have a voice and are valued members of the health care team. There are many professional development opportunities to encourage lifelong learning and professional growth and advancement of nurses throughout the system. As a system, we have the unique opportunity to serve and meet the needs of our community.
cons: We don't get as much recognition for all of the great things we do in serving others.

review_title: I would not recommend this place
pros: Pros of the job -medical benefits, retirement plans, vacation time and very lenient sick time policy.
cons: The workload is too much to bear.  Expectations of management cannot be met and management offers little support. Administration wants to run lean but does so at the expense of employee morale and engagement leading to quick burnout. There is no work/life balance. Vacation days are spent working from home to simply stay on top of your job.  Projects rarely have resolution due to lack of time and manpower to compete. Technology is outdated.

pros:
I have been treated with respect since my first day on May 7th.  Albeit I'm in excellent physical condition,  I am, let's just say, a little more mature than most new officers in my profession.  The fact that I was offered an opportunity to serve our patients and staff says a lot.  Metro recognized my life long experience and gave me an opportunity. 

I have worked at main campus and experienced three satellite locations.  Each place, my co-workers from every level of service have shown me deference and admiration, and have come to me for advice to resolve issues regardless of my entry level experience.  Everyone has made me feel and know I made the right choice  to accept my position.  

I have not yet met a person who hasn't greeted me with a smile.  A few times I needed to visit the main campus, prior to knowing the layout.  I was off duty and didn't have my badge displayed.  I apparently looked lost, and, our people were outgoing to ask me if I was lost, and escorted me to the proper area.

This is the same every location I have worked or visited.  What magic do you possess to instill this caring attitude in thousands of people?  My answer!  This welcoming, warm, and open arms attitude emanates from the top and trickles down.  Please continue what you are doing!  This positive attitude has reached every level of employee.

Keep up the good work.
cons: I seriously have no complaints or suggestions of improvement.

review_title: I had a wonderful experience working with the individuals at The MetroHealth System.
pros: The employees are wonderful, the current CEO is a change maker and listens to the little people.
cons: Relationships of Upper Management and the Management of Labor Relations does not make for a very favorable environment for employees in certain departments.

review_title: Can Be A Great Place To Work
pros: Administrative Support to physicians, who were wonderful, and who care about their patients.
cons: Very political.  Often there, it's not what you know, but, who you know to be promoted, etc.  People are put into positions because of their "ties", and not for their experience/skills/knowledge.  Left after seven years, since I became frustrated with the department:(

pros:
The list of positives at MetroHealth is long: a wonderful mission, a staff that not only believes in that mission but LIVES it, great benefits, smart leadership, a growing and expanding system, stability, a great future with the campus transformation. 

Most of all, it's that knowledge that you and your colleagues are working to improve the health of the community. There is no higher calling.
cons: The bureaucracy can sometimes be frustrating.

review_title: Loved Metrohealth as a patient and love it even more as an employee.
pros: From leadership to the maintenance staff is extremely nice and caring. Most employees are very passionate about what they do and what Metrohealth does.
cons: Communication can be difficult because it is such a large hospital. And the facility is not the best, it is pretty aged but this will not longer be a problem with the new hospital being built.

review_title: One of the best employers I have worked for
pros:
MetroHealth has many career advancement opportunities with a focus on hire within.
Good benefit package
Most of the staff  are customer service oriented.
fast pace environment
cons:
Depending on the deparment and job function, you may work more hours than you want.
Communication between departments is poor.
Due to many layoffs and cutbacks, employees are faced with doing more with less.

pros:
Passionate, medical staff dedicated to caring for all and helping to train future generation of health providers. Faculty include national leaders in their fields. Psychologists are highly valued members of the medical staff and enjoy parity with physicians. Metro finds ways to care for patients in need.
The benefits (especially retirement system) are excellent.
cons: Metro competes with other health care systems in the region who have greater financial resources and budgets. I often wish we had more of a financial cushion to support our good work.

review_title: Great potential and moving in the right direction
pros: More structure and processes were put into place that righted the ship.  The staff at every level was passionate about the mission and providing the best possible care to patients and families.  The new leadership is fulfilling much of the untapped potential.
cons: Can be a bit bureaucratic and sometimes they get in their own way.  If they continue to streamline systems, there will be quicker turnaround time.

review_title: I work at MetroHealth because I believe in MH mission to serve the community
pros: It is a wonderful place to work- it is Mission oriented and you make a real difference in the lives of people that you take care of. You are surrounded by other people who share the same values. In addition to clinical work, I enjoy the academic and teaching opportunities to train the next generation of physicians and healthcare providers.
cons: Administrative processes can sometime be onerous but you can get things done

pros: I have only been here a short time, but it's a hospital that is committed to bettering the community. I must say that everyone is very supportive. One day, I was clearly lost while trying to find another office. A doctor stopped what he was doing to ask me where I was going. He proceded to show me the correct way to the office. I thought it was a very nice gesture.
cons: I haven't been there long enough to have any cons.

review_title: MetroHealth = Great Mission + Awesome People + Proud Supporter of the LGBT Community
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Cleveland, OH
pros:
Wonderful mission to serve all people regardless of their ability to pay.
Great coworkers and a supportive culture.
Progressive policies and strong supporter of the LGBT Community
Benefits and retirement
cons:
Lots of work to do, but work life balance is respected.
Limited resources/personnel

job_title: Social Work Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: Everything! I joined the Metro Team 8 months ago, and it immediately felt like home. I know this is the place I will grow and retire from. I have never had such amazing work/life balance, team members, benefits, pay, and friendships. Most importantly my managers see my worth and tell me how much they appreciate me. This work environment is something I have never experienced before, and I am so very grateful.
cons: I do not have any cons.

review_title: Believe in this organization and the transformation underway
job_title: Director of Operations in Cleveland, OH
pros: I have chosen to spend my career at MetroHealth based on the organization's commitment to its mission and the community.  This is an exciting time to work at MetroHealth as our transformation will not only remedy our aging infrastructure, but will also address determinants of health beyond the scope of traditional medicine to help create a much healthier community.
cons: The aging infrastructure of the main hospital (which will be replaced by 2022).

review_title: MetroHealth the best hospital in the City of Cleveland
job_title: Support Center Analyst in Cleveland, OH
pros: Comradarie with fellow employees. Management supports it's employees. I worked in Pathology for 19 years and went to another job. When offered to come back I was very happy.
cons: Issues sometimes become pressing and can frustrate but it all gets resolved with all hands on the wheel.

pros: great learning environment, opportunity to grow,
cons: objective views brought in to make change is a great approach, but needs to be tempered by acknowledging experience already in place has a place in that change as well

review_title: MetroHealth is a great place to work.
pros: The MetroHealth staff share a common mission and purpose, to provide outstanding health care to everyone, including the indigent and the underserved. Working in this type of environment and with other people who share my values and purpose is the reason I went into medicine in the first place. Metro makes me feel happy that I chose this profession.
cons: Our government should provide more support for safety new hospitals, such as MetroHealth.

pros: Started at MetroHealth in 1987 as a new RN.  If I wouldn't have left I could be retired by now. They truly live their mission to serve those in need in Cuyahoga County.  Excellent trauma services.
cons: It takes HR too long to approve and hire new nurses, so we work short staffed much of the time.

review_title: How much longer will I be there?
pros:
Interesting environment
Fast paced 
Cafeteria food is actually good
Friendly employees
cons:
Favortism shown towards those who suck up to management while others are expected to fill in for the work they do not perform
Lack of motivation by management
Lack of training
Poor communication between departments
A lot of finger pointing (not my problem)

review_title: Excellent place to work, excellent patient care and facilities, but dense dense with Management.
pros: Excellent facilities and Professional Medical Staff. Excellent support staff.
cons: Dense with redundant management partly due to extensive Government regulatory requirements.

review_title: The place is a great place to learn.
pros: The people there are always willing to help you no matter what. I really enjoyed working with everyone there. Felt very comfortable working there.
cons: Due to the recent PR and scrutiny, it sometimes is a little hard to explain the circumstances to people. Many are quick to judge.

review_title: Come to work here if you want to make a difference!
pros: This place is on the move, doing great things in the community and growing every day. Co-workers are supportive. Leadership is strong. Professional development is encouraged. And patients are at the center of everything MetroHealth does.
cons: Muddling through the paperwork here can slow you down.

job_title: Director of Nursing in Cleveland, OH
pros: MHS is a very welcoming and warm environment. The patients feel validated and heard.; not treated as a "number".  As an employee, I have many options for care outside of MHS; and I would not ever want to be a patient anywhere else.
cons: I cannot think of any worth worrying about...

job_title: Referral Office Liaison in Brooklyn Heights, Cuyahoga, OH
pros: The retirement and health benefits are the only positive things about MH.
cons:
1.) MH is stuck in the past. Their technology is so outdated, and it takes months for IT to fix the simplest of issues.

2.) MH does not care about patients. Managers always come up with excuses about why they cannot talk to patients who want calls escalated. Offering to put patients on a wait list? It doesn't matter- nobody is calling to add patients onto the schedule because we are so understaffed. There is one manager in particular in a department who nobody feels supported by, yet that person still works at MH somehow.

3.) MH constantly lets go of amazing employees. One of our former employees was awesome, she actually wanted to make changes and improve morale in the call center- what happened? She was fired, without cause and without notice.

4.) MH loves to have MBAs run healthcare. This is a huge problem for healthcare in general. Our dept head demoted fantastic employees, fired employees who actually care about patients, and has driven over 10 people to quit in the past year. When I resigned, they didn't even offer an exit interview (but they gripe about not understanding why nobody stays). 

5.) HR does not care about employees at all. I tried not to let the disorganized on-boarding process negatively influence my opinions about MH, but the longer I worked there, the more I realized it's a system-wide issue. People are lazy and rude- many employees are just waiting for their retirement money and don't care about providing good care to patients.

6.) Constant issues with getting things done for patients. Guess what we can't do? Call your doctor or nurse's office. They don't even let us have their office #s. Those who run the hospital understaff the front offices so badly that they can't take calls and it often takes MONTHS for patients to get issues resolved, especially if it involves paperwork. I will never recommend this mess of an organization for anyone looking to get excellent healthcare- this outfit doesn't care about your health, your needs, your family, or anything that you might need beyond the basic check-up. 

All Metro cares about is your money. You are a number, and this is why so many doctors leave Metro within a year or two of being hired on--just wait, if your doctor hasn't left yet, they will.

review_title: The most fulfilling job I've ever had
job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in Cleveland, OH
pros: MetroHealth's incredible mission of service. The inspiring doctors, nurses and other colleagues who have dedicated their professional lives to the health of the community. Smart executive leadership. Solid pay/benefits. A new main hospital under construction!
cons: While it gets better every day, MetroHealth is still trying to shake off some of its long-held bureaucracies.

pros:
Great experience & it is what you make it. Just like any place, come in with a great attitude
& good work ethic & that will reap great benefits not only for you but the patient, their family & your team as well.
cons: Staffing can be low

review_title: Family-oriented team working together to make Northeast Ohio healthier one patient at a time
pros: The environment is collaborative and people come together to work as a team to help people get healthier while at the some time addressing some of our community's most pressing and persistent issues.
cons: Main Campus is a series of large buildings that can be difficult to navigate.

review_title: Have worked here multiple times over the last 13 years
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Middleburg Heights, OH
pros: Good benefits and compensation is competitive.  Metro has some of the most dedicated long term employees
cons: Sr Management has been very transient over the past decade resulting in multiple re-orgs

review_title: Metrohealth is my second home, colleagues and staff are my extended family.
pros: Great mission, wonderful staff , team work, providing great unique services to our patients and community. Opportunities for growth and promotion. Welcoming and collegial culture.
cons: Keeping up with rapid changes in health care .

review_title: Many leaders-not enough followers-sometimes not enough productivity of co-workers
pros: Good shift hours offered, there is always options for resource choices
cons: Too many emails used instead of phoning the staff. Too many advertisement sent to employees instead of using intra-net.Save the postage --theres a great idea.

job_title: Medical Student Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: There is a general feeling of "family" between co-workers, faculty & staff.  All patients are treated the same, no matter what their social or financial status.  Employees go out of their way to help patients and visitors.
cons: As in many places, positions have been cut, and the work load is heavy.

pros: Decent benefits. Salary is competitive.
cons: This place is not for new nurses. I went to a prestigious nursing school. Thus was my first RN job after school. This place does not take the time, nor provide the resources a new grad nurse needs. They do not help you, then they rip you up in reviews. Not at all what a new nurse needs to be successful.

pros: The people are like family and really care about each other.  Employees care about the mission and have good values.
cons: See people who have physical or health problems and for non-clinical employees, it may be hard to see.

pros: If interested in medical field you will see all different kinds of specialists, different kinds of diagnosis and gain tons of patient care experience. If you wanted many hours, you will be able to get them!
cons: Have to work 1 Winter holiday and 1 summer holiday.

job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Brooklyn Heights, Cuyahoga, OH
pros: Great leaders, great communication, awesome benefits (no deductibles or copays if seen by MetroHealth providers), amazing response/preparedness and communication related to COVID-19.
cons: Some of the buildings and facilities are aging. Good thing our brand new hospital will be done in 2022!!

pros: Benefits that include medical and life insurance; accruing vacation and sick days, tuition reimbursement.
